Trying to be nuanced on twitter dot com is the most sisyphean task I've ever done but I cannot stop it

When it comes to Xochitl specifically, it was just a mistake by Marvel, there's nothing else to be said here. She's not white, but her skin is light, and MAC never had light skin. That's just colorism again. That doesn't mean we'll attack her, tho, she's still a child.

I will always defend the interpretation that America is Afro-Latina because in many books she is, that is indisputable. But the same can be said for the interpretation that she's native. And I think that's where the friction in the fandom comes from. They're both right.

The thing is when Marvel was presented with a choice, they were NEVER going to make her canonically Black, because it is more profitable for them if she isn't, because she sells better if she isn't, she's more accepted if she isn't. Because colorism exists.
Because it's complicated, right? What takes precedence? Her original book where she's coded more as mestiza or native, or books like Ultimates where she's clearly drawn as a Black woman?

The issue is nuanced, though. Like I've tried to explained before, while America has been coded as Black in the comics many times, there's also been many stories in which she isn't, and *there* to me is where the issue comes in.

I made a thread the other day explaining why she isn't necessarily Puerto Rican, and I maintain that, she isn't, but as I've explained over and over again, nationality and race aren't the same and one thing doesn't change the other. The reading that MAC is afro-latina is valid.

This is a very good and informative thread. I feel like many people think I don't agree with this because I defend Xochitl as a person, and I try to be neutral and explain things without taking sides, but I'll say this: the casting is, at the very least, unquestionably colorist. twitter.com/sk8terboypercy‚Ä¶

Like, I am, in fact, not stupid, I understand there are out of universe reasons for why Bruce and Gotham are the way they are. My discussion is Watsonian in nature, to then extrapolate into the real world. It has very real merit.
I think some people are seeing this criticism as a reason why "Batman wouldn't make sense". That's not the case at all. Batman makes perfect sense, which it should be discussed critically.

I know (most) ppl aren't malicious when they dismiss this take, but the anger yall show whenever it happens kinda makes you sound like an NFT bro when ppl point out it's a nerd's pyramid scheme twitter.com/LetsTalkMAC/st‚Ä¶

@LetsTalkMAC Also I see writers and reviewers CONSTANTLY saying that XYZ Batman story wants to be grounded in reality and real problems and injustice etc. But at the same time they don't want the criticism/discussion that comes with addressing these issues.

@LetsTalkMAC and activism. She's 'evil' and 'crazy.' She's a 'killer' (nevermind he's literally a man who dresses in an animal costume and uses violence, fear, and torture to wage his war on crime.)

There IS a message being sent there

@LetsTalkMAC This is my problem with the situation. Bruce represents whiteness, the wealthy, the patriarchy. He's presented as intellectually and morally correct/honest, even among other heroes (he's always right).

While they vilify Ivy, who represents queerness, feminism, environmentalism,

And I know the standard responses, I know that he donates money, I know that we're supposed to believe that Gotham is especially evil or whatever, but honestly, none of it matters. For as long as Bruce is a billionaire, he cannot effect real social change.

And to hail a billionaire as the only one who can save the city, not by distributing his wealth *in an effective way*, but by beating people up, is a problem. And is a relevant problem for our real life society today.
Again, this is not about *Bruce*, this is about understanding economic inequality. Gotham isn't the way it is because of the crime, the crime exists because of massive inequality.

I think it's important to point out that for Bruce Wayne to be a billionaire, he *has* to steal money from workers. Because that's how capitalism works. It doesn't matter how much money he donates or whatever, his mere existence makes Gotham less equal.

this isn't do dismiss Batman in particular, yall can wank Bruce for all I care. like, this is important shit. *Especially* when we currently have a large group of people who are praising a real life billionaire as a savior of our species.

"he's just a fictional character" well, yeah, but one of the roles of fiction is being analyzed and criticized. Batman in particular can be a good way of discussing impact of wealth on disadvantaged communities, and our perception of what who can save them and how.
Anti-capitalism Batman takes are and always will be valid and relevant

But we don't always get what we want, and the nature of comics is obviously very fluid. It's entirely possible that this retcon isn't true, or that isn't final, or that it'll revert back someday. Most longtime comic book characters have gone through similar changes.

Would I have done anything different? Probably, yeah. Including a white man in her origin is ill advised at best. If her mothers were human and had simply been trying to cure her and somehow ended up in the Parallel as we know it, I think everyone would've embraced the change.

We don't actually know a whole lot about America's role in the MCU as one right now, but we do have a leaked audition, and it's relevant to say that this audition aligns very well to what we know about America from Made in the USA. I highly doubt it's a coincidence.

But the longtime fans aren't the only fans that exist. America is already a part of the Rising franchise (and her origin there has many similarities with the retcon), and she'll be in the MCU starting next year. America is for those fans too.

Personally, I spent the entire day yesterday trying to figure out how I felt about it, what I liked and disliked. And I'm still not really sure? It's a major change to a character I love, I don't think myself or any of her longtime fans will assimilate everything any time soon.

It's impossible to say right now whether this retcon will ultimately be for the best or for the worst, we'll only really know years from now, or at the very least once Made in the USA is complete. I think it can be a positive change, if it's dealt with correctly.

And tbh, we can kinda see this already. There's a new influx of MAC fans that came with Made in the USA, that either never got America from her previous appearances or never had any interest in her. The response from new fans to the retcon has been largely positive.

People always had issues with that idea, myself included, but it's unquestionably a good thing that this is no longer a problem, and likely was THE big reason why the retcon exists in the first place. It makes America more palatable and more marketable to larger audiences.

But it's not all bad news. This retcon solves the biggest criticism America's faced since her backstory was established. There was a line of thought that believed America wasn't actually Latine representation because she wasn't actually from Latin America. This has been fixed

Is America's relationship with the Demiurge still the same? Does it even exist? What about America's grandmother, Madrimar, and everything she told her in her solo? Is America no longer unique in the multiverse? probably not. Are Fuertonas still a thing? I hope not.

America's previous solo, America (2017) can be almost entirely discarded if this retcon is actually accurate. Everything that happened in that book would be either pure imagination, manipulation, or just isn't canon anymore (some people find this a positive thing).

There's also the question of everything that came before Made in the USA. Many of America's stories before this book link her directly to the multiverse, to her heritage, and to her mothers' sacrifice. It's valid to wonder if that has any meaning anymore.

Is this retcon a good or a bad thing? It depends. Most America fans don't seem to like it. The main argument is that this makes America's origin less original. And indeed, I was talking to @SpiderWomnDaily and the similarities of this origin to Jessica Drew's are many, for one

In fact, not of this has actually been confirmed as truth. Made in the USA is an ongoing book and we don't have all the answers. A lot can change between now and the time the final issue comes out, likely in August, but for now, we can speculate.
Right now we believe that this experiment, that supposedly exposed America to a magical multidimensional magic is what gave her powers. That hasn't been entirely confirmed. https://t.co/GiwQCndAEK

After yesterday, this is not necessarily the case. According to Made in the USA #3, America and her family are humans. Her mothers are scientists who tried to cure America of a disease called Edges Syndrome, along with other young girls. https://t.co/WVAX9HJM29
When the Parallel faced destruction, her mothers sacrificed themselves to everyone. America, moved by their sacrificed, fled that Utopia to live as a hero in the multiverse. https://t.co/p7p57rRALN

America's backstory as we knew was first explained in Young Avengers (2013) #14. According to America herself, she lived in an utopian reality called the Utopian Parallel. That reality was created by the Demiurge, and housed only women. https://t.co/lIYzx3sa71

I'm excited about what's to come next. It's just that simple. This issue was really well written, it looks amazing, and it gave me all the confidence that we're going in the right direction with America's character. This is a solid 9/10.

What I love about the issue is that it doesn't just tell us MAC's story, or how she is, or how strong she's supposed to be. It does a really good job of showing everything to the audience, including her love for a family we didn't even know existed. https://t.co/2pLTkRplRs

Honestly? I'm not sure this first issue could be much better than this. Yeah, there are a few issues, some of the dialogue didn't work for me, Spider-Man's cameo is completely pointless, but overall, this is exactly what America needs.

I really love this sequence. A fire is by far not the most challenging thing America's faced, but there's a strong sense of urgency and heft to her movements. MAC feels powerful, even if what she's doing is comparably simple. Another good job by Carlos. https://t.co/qoHW1tca3M

This legitimately broke my heart. Like I said before, family is what drives America, and Kalinda shows that really well. It's undeniable that the Santana's are her family too, and you can Feel how scared she is for them. Really good stuff. https://t.co/lErHIscAlM

Not only America looks incredibly fierce here, this is arguably a new use of her powers ‚Äî breaking a barrier instead of punching a hole in the multiverse. I doubt this will come up often, but it's pretty awesome regardless. https://t.co/4SoJjiMgVh
The narration here implies whoever is behind what's happening knows America from her childhood in NY, not the Parallel. I'm not sure if I completely buy this yet. https://t.co/IwxVOMYHmD

This is honestly one of my new favorites America panels ever. Carlos Gomez and Jesus Aburtov shine throughout this issue, but this is particularly incredible imo https://t.co/21R8fdOIpu

It's also important to note that the Santana's are from San Juan, America's adopted family still is Nuyorican (though they seemed to have moved from the Bronx to Washington Heights), and it's more reason to be disappointed at the MCU choice.

Even as a child, America was, understandably, closed off. It's another consistent character trait that has been badly missed since Ultimates. I love the way Kalinda sets this up here, you can really see why she is the way she is. https://t.co/rZHTHFXFpD

We might be getting a new origin but one thing doesn't change: everything in America's life revolves around family. It's a character trait that should never go away. I can only imagine how big this moment might be for her. https://t.co/hMHWqMRXcW
Not super relevant but Ramone looks so cool just look at her I'm in love https://t.co/09gfimtU9a

HOWEVER, I am open to the possibility that this girl might somehow be involved with the antagonist of this story, which is why she already knows everything. I also want to point out that America doesn't actually share anything new with her. She's still private. https://t.co/dq2R3fU7tG

Most of the reviews I read took issue with this scene in particular, and I gotta say I agree. It was probably a way of Kalinda helping readers catching up with MAC's established backstory, but America is such a secretive person, it's hard to imagine someone would know all of it. https://t.co/1b4mSVV0Ld

Going back to the present, America's dialogue during the fight with the moles felt a little clunky to me, but that mostly goes away as the issue progresses. It feels to me like Kalinda figuring out her voice, which is understandable. We've seen worse. https://t.co/rhgVqImaoc

Also, let me just say that I love Javi already. You can tell he could've been a great influence in America's life and her strong sense of morality. He does the right thing first, and cares about the consequences later. https://t.co/VIYgxVm4oi

Actual Latinxs being a big part of MAC's story is also relevant because it gives her an undeniable connection to our culture. It also highlights a crucial analogy for the character: America Chavez is an immigrant. An alien in every sense of the word. https://t.co/W3dARKtdHz

There's not much we know about them yet, but this is very important regardless. These people matter to America, they're her family, they have to be more than random names on a page like on her previous solo. It's a great step in the right direction.

The first page gives us the first addition and change MAC's backstory. Previously what we knew was that America was raised by 'Abuela Santana', who was the first person who found her after arriving to Earth. Kalinda gives us a full fledged family instead. https://t.co/w8MUVAVLYJ

All in all, I'm very happy with the result. It's exactly what the character and the fans needed after almost 4 years of getting dunked on. I'd be following the book regardless for obvious reasons, but after today I'm even more hyped than I already was.

I have a few minor complaints that I will get into when I do my spoiler filled review, but it's nothing that took me out of the book and it's nothing that hurts in the long run. Just some missteps that honestly might only exist because it's the first issue.

The chances to the backstory so far are minor, but there's a lot of weight to them by the way it's integrated to the story. I have no doubts more chances will come, but the specifics dont matter as much as how they serve to explain who MAC is. They're on the right direction.
This feels so much like the America I love, the America I honestly hadn't seen since Ultimates. Kalinda starts off very well with her portrayal and it made me more excited about this book than ever.

But what I'm most interested in is the writing and how Kalinda is tackling both America's characterization and her origin story. It was only one issue, but I'm very happy with what I found, specifically when it comes to her character.

Starting with the most obvious: the book *looks* great. For all the shit I've given Carlos this past few months, he's insanely talented, and the colors definitely add to it. America looks incredible. The art's gonna win over a lot of people.

And it's not just the fans who do this btw, I've said it before. This is the reason why Latinx characters usually have a wide range of skin tones over the years. Nobody has a clue as to what we look like and nobody bothers to check. Again, it leads to erasure.

The idea that White Latinxs looked different (read: tanned) from white ppl anywhere else comes from internalized xenophobia and colorism. I don't have to begin to explain why that's problematic. Unlearn it.

A quick cheat sheet: White Latinxs are, like, White people. Like the ones you have over there? The word you're looking for when you think White Latinx is mixed (or mestizx, or pardx, or mulattx, depending on where you are and who you're talking about)

I think there's definitely merit in understanding your fandom and your community and finding ways to engage with them in a way that's satisfying for both, but it's never going to be as simple as we sometimes want to believe
And that's not even mentioning that setting out to do "what fans want" will inevitably give any creator unrealistic expectations that nobody wants to sign up for.
How exactly will DC or Marvel or whoever will give us "what the fans want" when fandoms spend half the time bickering about shit as simple as best costumes or best teams or power levels
Starting with the fact that "the fans" are millions of people, each one with different opinions, and often what we assume "the fans" want are just what our immediate circle thinks

There's been a lot of talk about 'what the fans want' lately particularly around DC and like, I get it, I sign up for that for sure, but I think it's also important to realize that it's more complicated than it sounds.

Whatever the case may be, I think she'll benefit from having better defined physical features and not letting each artist change her on a whim. It's a problem when shes light brown with wavy hair in one issue and dark skinned with curly hair in another.

So if you'd like to see another incredible Queer Woman of Color kick ass in the MCU, you better hope today's rumors are true. America is a gift, and I can't wait to finally see her on the big screen.

When you really get to know her story, it's not surprise she might show up in a movie literally called *in the madness of the multiverse*. It's unclear how relevant she would be to the plot, but the connection is there.
This is America Chavez. An indestructible hero, a traveler, a powerhouse of compassion and love, a leader, one of the strongest characters in the Marvel Universe. https://t.co/tscOfRTw9B

America is also a bilingual brown woman and a Lesbian. Those identities don't often play a role in her stories, btu they're an important part of her, and we've been lucky to get a couple of great canon ships for her. https://t.co/UGxiYgv7Kb

After that, she became a hero in the marvel universe, fighting injustice wherever she found it and, more relevantly, learning about and protecting the multiverse itself. She was once described as "paramedic for the multiverse". https://t.co/riiIQHf6Zo
At first America landed on Earth, and was taken by a Nuyorican family. They cared for her until she decided to travel. That's when her identity as a Latina was developed. https://t.co/9vzmZ4BYMv

When she was six years old, her dimension was nearly destroyed, but ultimately saved by America's mothers' sacrifice. After that, she left paradise to be a hero like her mothers and make them proud. https://t.co/np6aDfeump

These abilities are innate. America is from a race called Fuertonas (yes, i know), a group of women who lived in an Utopian dimension disconnected from multiverse. She's said to be one of the most naturally gifted among the Fuertonas (yes, i know). https://t.co/a5MgAZABH4

In both instances, she was considered to be the powerhouse, that is, the physically strongest member of each team. Not only is she strong, she's also super fast, invulnerable, can fly, and most importantly, open star-shaped portals to different dimensions. https://t.co/xFlrpzQQtj

America was created in 2011 by Joe Casey & Nick Dragotta in the Vengeance mini-series. She later gained popularity as member of the Young Avengers by Kieron Gillen and Jamie McKelvie in 2013. https://t.co/91CqAwTrry

@LetsTalkMAC This is what kills me about writing accents. I always write things properly on the first draft and then switch out the right words depending on the accent.

I guess the big difference between America and Steve in that regard is that Steve is the guy who speaks up and tries to reason to people? America ain't about that. She'll speak through actions and give ppl a chance to understand shit on their own.

ALSO I love it when people hate on Steve and are like oh he thinks he knows better than everyone!! everything has to be his way!! cause like, America is exactly the same? She literally joined The Ultimates bc she knew they'd fuck up and she wanted to be there to say I told you so

they're all very different people, obviously, and the flavor is what makes them interesting and what makes us prefer one over the other (I love all of them very much), but like, there's a reason why all these people have been Captain America/Patriot at some point lmao

but at their core, they're very similar. they all hold themselves to impossibly high moral standards and try to live up to a legacy or a symbol at the best of their abilities (her moms/Demiurge for America). and social/political commentary is present in many of their stories.

really, the only like huge differences between America and Steve/Bucky/Sam/Eli/Rayshaun/Rikki/et al. in terms of storytelling is the universes they're mostly used in. America is cosmic while the others are street lvl/espionage.
@LetsTalkMAC You should do it!
@LetsTalkMAC They should care. Eli's more important to Mac than most people know. His absence is actually the reason why America was brought into YA and had her image transformed.

it's funny tho, how sometimes it feels like it's a surprise to some people how much I care about Cap and Eli and all the Amerifam, really. They're so much more similar to America than so many people realize

ALSO to say that Nat died only for Clint and not also because she was ready & desperate to do anything she possibly could to save the universe is to cheapen her sacrifice and a disservice to her character

The one thing we should never, ever do is use fanom to criticize canon. If your headcanon is that Steve and Nat loved Tony too much to go 5 years without talking to him, great, that's awesome. But you can't be mad at the movie for not following that.

Would it be better if they were all one giant happy family where everyone supports each other and agree with everything? Obviously. But it's not what happened. And that's been consistent throughout the MCU. They're a team, but they bicker and they disagree and they fight.

Like, it's not crazy to assume Tony didn't WANT Steve and Nat (who betrayed him at the end of CW) to check up on him. And Thor isolated himself, as depressed people often do. The battle was over, they lost, people moved on.

For years people complained Civil War wouldn't have any lasting repercussions, but this is it. it's literally it. Tony still was very clearly pissed off over what happened, rightfully so. Their relationship was shattered.

I understand where the fandom's coming from when they say they wished the MCU Avengers had been closer and better friends through the years and especially in the 5 years gap in Endgame but idk fam, it's a lot more complicated than that

10. First because she's looking for some answers that she might not find at home and second because she stumbled upon power and she wants to use that power to protect everything she loves. she has a really strong sense of duty and it appeals to that.

9. As if it couldn't be any more obvious, she's Lawful Good. Leans more towards goodness than lawfulness but things like society, rules, and tradition most of all mean a lot to her. being a Dwarf has a big impact on that
8. Her main goal is to know more about her family's history and their connection to Arcane magic, and eventually use what she finds to protect all the goodness in the world.
7. Elrin is the kind of character who genuinely thinks everyone is her friend, but she tends to make an extra effort to be close to closed off people, which can go really badly real fast tbqh

as for the fandom drama (?), I understand where both sides are coming from. I'm sure there are people who aren't into Ramone because of colorism, there's no denying that. I also understand that ppl have been invested in Amerikate since 2013.

so far I like what I see of their relationship and I'm thankful that it exists. I wish they had more panel time to actually develop their connection, but it's still very much recent. they're on the right track.

back to WCA, I will say that it bothered me a little that America didn't show much concern for Ramone until the very end ‚Äî I was Fully expecting Ramone to break up with her right there ‚Äî but to be fair, that's who America is. She worries about getting the job done first.

I find it very odd how we didn't get more kisses in America's solo tbh. it was Supposed to show America's personal life, and everyone knows she's really freaking gay. it didn't help that she broke up with Lisa on #1 I guess.

I say /real/ kiss, because we got close so far, but I don't count them? 1. America and Lisa are hidden in the shadows, only implied to be kissing 2. the art is unclear on whether there is an actual kiss, and Magdalena was poisoning her 3. Non-consensual kiss, more poisoning https://t.co/en8KFWrkc3

here's the deal: unless I'm terribly mistaken (which is possible), this is America's first /real/ kiss on-panel. it's crazy we've had to wait almost 8 years and 4 romantic interests, including a long time girlfriend, to get here. it was a beautiful kiss, though. https://t.co/ptjIHfCJjA
it just hit me that I was so worried about spoiling the last issue of WCA that I ended up never really talking about America & Ramone, so bear with me for a second.

What if Floyd truly was a hero on his first apparition but was Clayface copying Floyd's appearance, hire the mercenaries, cheated batman and all his first stay in prision was a mistake that came Floyd insane?

CW gets away with so much racism and xenophobia and homophobia and misogyny, just because it adds some lesbians and POC in the background and everyone calls it progressive or the epitome of representation. That's Not Enough

And I don't mean to say that the Arrowverse Must Be Cancelled Forever or that Everyone Involved Are Horrible People or that If You Liked The Episode You're Literal Human Trash. It's not about that. I'm just saying you should be aware of it, and CW has to do better

That only serves to reinforce the idea that all Latinxs are dangerous and violent and inherently connected to illegality. And if you think that doesn't matter, take a quick look at the news, see what's happening to Latinx immigrants in the US right now.

Just do one exercise for me: think of any productions (tv or movie) set anywhere in Latin America. How many can you think of that didn't involve, or was straight about, murder, kidnapping or drug trafficking.

Because this was mentioned a lot: I'm sure nobody was trying to be offensive, I'm sure it was just for fun, and I'm sure everyone involved had a jolly good time working on it

It doesn't mean it's not harmful and it doesn't mean people won't be offended by it twitter.com/LetsTalkMAC/st‚Ä¶

@LetsTalkChase It's not pointless at all! We should always push for more representation and Better representation. It's just hard for me to be more assertive if I don't know his personal history, ya know? All I read of him is Champions

@LetsTalkMAC Yeah, you pretty much summarized how pointless my rage over this detail is. At the end of the day, we still have a half Puerto Rican Spider-Man. Whether people care of not, it's still a win for us, I guess.

@LetsTalkChase I can't say anything for sure before I read more, but I guess it depends on how connected he is with the Puerto Rican side of his family? Because not everyone cares about that stuff ya know? But yeah, as a general rule, cultural backgrounds should Always be appreciated

@LetsTalkMAC That's actually what I wanted to talk about: the fact that, in my opinion, his Latinx side is highly underappreciated by Marvel. It's not that bad, but it could be better. I say this as a fellow Puerto Rican.
@LetsTalkChase I haven't read enough of his solo stuff to say anything for sure, but more Latinx representation is always nice
@Tuckerscreator Tbh I read that as America picturing a life with Kate + Lucky when she thinks of a perfect future for herself but I might be pushing it haha

@Tuckerscreator That probably has to do with her abandonment issues tbh. As much as America longs for family, she's constantly pushing people away so they won't have the opportunity to leave her. Makes sense for the character

@Tuckerscreator I feel like that's nitpicking honestly. There isn't One Latinx culture, but our cultures coexist and there's a lot of shared history here. Plus, when you travel from place to place like America did, you end up picking up stuff from different cultures, it's only natural

@LetsTalkMAC This is completely off-topic but:

How do you feel about Miles Morales being half Puerto-Rican?

@LetsTalkMAC Dangnabbit, and the opening page implies Storm remembers their meetup too.

@LetsTalkMAC Me, I found it interesting but I remember thinking: ‚ÄúSo she just wandered all alone as a child for years and avoided keeping family or friends? Geez, if I had no family for that long I feel like I would‚Äôve gotten really messed up.‚Äù

@LetsTalkMAC I remember this page was controversial because some didn‚Äôt like the implication there‚Äôs a ‚Äúuniversal‚Äù Latinx culture or that America could seemingly cherry-pick from it and move on.

this is Easily the best issue so far. one of the best in the entire run. other than the Madrimar stuff, everything works well and you can see how good it could've been with tighter writing. I really do like this one.
and then they never saw each other again https://t.co/c1xNIJ6jRz
asiuhdas dumb https://t.co/CTgd1kNYHw

"all it takes is one second of trust." it's so good to see America becoming better, more attune with the multiverse because she deals with her feelings. it could've been more subtle than this, but this actually Works. I like it so much. https://t.co/qJu9ZvQC02
also it's interesting how she blames herself even though it was very clear that it was Lisa's decision to leave https://t.co/4wfPAT9XaC
abandonment issues thy name is america chavez https://t.co/X2S5BrkD9g
THIS BOOK COULD'VE BEEN SO GOOD https://t.co/NKyTlu9p3z
I'll never get over this lmao https://t.co/FYUguP0WZf

but ugh @ America's line. this is only to set up Madrimar's """reveal""" but it should be Obvious that America has ancestors. She does everything she does for her mothers. Just because she can't reach them or don't know them, it doesn't mean they never existed

"There's no shame in being afraid" is also something she needs to hear. America has no idea how to deal with failure, and she doesn't let herself be afraid because of it, Ever. https://t.co/qya4DQ9NVV

the journey Gabby puts America through in this first arc is actually interesting and very relevant to the character. where she fails is on the dialogue and the pacing, but the rest isn't actually that bad at all.
this is actually not bad at all. America does have trouble when she has to confront her feelings, so she needs this. https://t.co/Br5jtZXgZM
it's so convenient that there's a random wrestling ring in the Astral Plane so we can have this dramatic panel of Madrimar laying down in the middle of it https://t.co/AyKpmC4gA8

punk Storm always looks So Good tho https://t.co/qeGioYXLfi
who tALKS like this, Gabby?????????????? https://t.co/0zVDdkns8G

the """""""""reveal""""""""" that Madrimar was America's grandma was so poorly done. there's never even a question of whether her intentions are good or not, where she knows America from or anything else. it's so incredibly boring. https://t.co/JK9EEk2XLT
making America identify as Puerto Rican is 100% Gabby inserting herself in her story but it's also 100% the right move imo. thematically, it makes perfect sense.

this is legit all I wanted from America since I first saw the character. for her to represent all Latinxs, to understand the Latinx experience, to live through it, and she does! she lived everywhere, she knows the culture, she connects to the people. that's the America we need.

She-hulk will always be sexy. Being confident in her body is a big part of her characterization, and there's nothing wrong with showing it. On the other hand it always felt out of place for characters like Rachel Grey to be sexualized bc nothing in her character asks for it.

And it's important to note that sexualized women aren't inherently a bad thing. Some women enjoy to present that way, and it's important to respect that. Women come in all sizes too, and it's okay to represent that. It's a problem when it goes against the story.
By unnatural I mean anything from unnatural bodies, to unnatural poses, unnatural clothing... You always can tell because it always stands out. It's designed to stand out.

@LetsTalkMAC But my rule of thumb is if you can see a professional wrestler wearing it, then there's no reason a superheroine couldn't

There's not one good answer for anything, but a good rule of thumb is if it feels unnatural or unnecessary, it's too much. That's when you know the artist is choosing to sexualize their work instead of telling the story. twitter.com/IVWall/status/‚Ä¶

This got a lot longer than I planned lmao. I just have a lot of feelings about America (2017)

I also feel like Gabby's inexperience with the media hurt the pacing a lot? I feel like the first issue alone could've been an entire arc. The first arc could've lasted 12 issues. At the very least it would e develop her relationships with Ororo and Peggy a lot better.
But I feel like the book actually ends in a much better position because Gabby actually fixes some of those problems. America feels more in character, she acts more and reacts less.
The other big problem with it I think is that America barely Does anything. Most of what goes down happens To her. That's just poor writing and does very little to develop the character.

Like I said, America was vulnerable before, but she'd just fought Thanos and she felt responsible for what happened to Rhodey. It was shocking to see her like that, but it made sense. In America, she's like that bc Gabby wrote her that way and that was it.

And tbh, in a solo book, these changes have to be made. America is The main character. She had to be vulnerable, we Have to know more about her, otherwise it's hard to sympathize with her. The problem imo is that it wasn't earned.
Not to mention she's a lot more willing to share about her personal history. Up until that point America was one of the most mysterious characters in Marvel. That book made sure to change that.

By the way, that second panel is actually a pretty good example of one of the problems people have with America's solo book. She's a lot more vulnerable and a lot less confident than she ever was in any of her previous appearances, except maybe after her first fight with Thanos. twitter.com/LetsTalkMAC/st‚Ä¶

SOLO RUN:
America (2017) #1-12

America's first solo book! It wasn't the most well-received book and it does has some ups and down, but it's still very positive. We learn more about America's personal history, as well as her family's, her powers and new friends. Also a must read. https://t.co/dfrAc9lixD

*NOTE. America is background character during Civil War II in this era. I don't recommend reading everything just for her, but here are some issues with good America moments:
Civil War II #1. Civil War II: Choosing Sides #2-3. Patsy Walker, A.K.A. Hellcat! #8 https://t.co/z5zOvRkSge

ULTIMATES ERA:
Avengers (2015) #0
Ultimates (2016) #1-12
Ultimates 2 (2017) #1-100

America finally becomes a bigger player in the Marvel Universe, joins and leads a super team, goes cosmic, and, last but not least, gets a girlfriend. My personal favorite era of hers tbh. https://t.co/A86QhSo1Bf

SECRET WARS ERA:
A-Force (2015) #1
Siege (2015) #1-4
Secret Wars Too (2015)

All part of the larger Secret Wars event. Not super necessary, but it's worth checking out for the many Amerikate moments. https://t.co/ZsMiOLj52A

YOUNG AVENGERS ERA:
Marvel Now! Point One (2012) #1
Young Avengers (2012) #1-15

The first appearance of the America Chavez most fans know and love. Establishes most of her characterization, powers, her sexuality, and best friends. Must read. https://t.co/lcpLyRpFTQ

FIRST APPEARANCE: 
Vengeance (2011) #1 - 6

Only notable for being America's first appearance. She's barely recognizable in comparison to later appearances, has a implied relationship with a man, and the art is very sexualized (America's 15 in this). Definitely skippable. https://t.co/BT11qia0YL
